In the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales of northern England, Jonny would drive a car on roads, while his younger brother Ali would race across the countryside on a mountain bike. 

"I'm looking forward to it," Jonny said at the start line. "I've never done anything like this before; it's exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it's very cold right now, so I'll be warm in the car." Alistair was also eager, but unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, he was dressed in full winter cycling gear. The cold didn't bother him. "To be honest," he said, "I've seen his driving before, so I'm not sure he'll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up."

The race began at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to finish at Yorkshire's highest road, Fleet Moss, 350 meters up. This was no problem for the car, but Alistair's first few miles involved a steep 25 percent incline, making it tough from the start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sprinted away on his bike, heading up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss, while Jonny jumped in the car and hit the road. The next time they would see each other would be at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny's early confidence was quickly challenged. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he encountered a giant tractor blocking the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he joked to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it's because of this farmer!" After tense moments, Jonny got past the tractor and continued into the morning mist. Meanwhile, Alistair struggled with the slope. A few miles in, he had to get off and carry his bike up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the summit. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun shining, he had a chance to show his skills. Head down, feet on the pedals, Alistair picked up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another local challenge. The villages in this part of Yorkshire have been around since before cars were invented, and the roads are not built for speed. Jonny carefully navigated a narrow corner and drove through a stream on the road. Once clear of the last village, he raced straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was flying across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping, he reached the line with a squeal of brakes. 

Finally, Alistair looked up. "Is he here?" he asked the waiting crowd. "No? Really?" He raised his arms in victory. "Yes!" Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car and stepped out. "Well done," Jonny said, clearly disappointed. "I'm gutted."

Playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon is a unique experience because of the silence. When you bounce the ball on the soft grass, you hear only the echo of your shots. The well-kept grass, the historic stadium, the players in white, and the respectful audience create a special atmosphere that feels separate from the outside world. This quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to block out everything except the game and the point I'm playing. The silence is only broken by applause and cheers when a point is won. Even though there are fifteen thousand people watching, I feel distant from them. I am so focused that I forget millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life.

I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach forever, taught me that Wimbledon is the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends that I would play and win there one day. Before 2008, I had played and lost twice to Federer, including the final the year before. Losing in 2006 wasn't too hard because I was just happy to be there at age twenty. Federer beat me easily because I didn't believe in myself enough. But losing in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have done better, and it was my mindset, not my skills, that let me down. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing is always painful, but it's worse when you know you had a chance. Toni, who is usually very tough on me, tried to comfort me, saying there would be more chances. I told him he didn't understand, thinking it was my last chance to win. I know a professional athlete's career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I felt I missed a big one in 2007. Toni couldn't ease my sadness, but he was right. Another chance came in 2008. I was confident I had learned from my defeat the year before, and I was determined not to let my mindset fail me again. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends, but we didn't talk about the match. They knew I was already mentally preparing for it, and I needed that space to be mine alone until the match began.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society helped make her famous by producing articles and TV documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is possibly the most celebrated female scientist of the 20th century, alongside Marie Curie. However, her fame might have overshadowed her real achievements. Many articles and books about her life often focus on her adventurous spirit or her role as a feminist, which can undervalue her actual work. Based on the number of academic references to her research, the success of her students, and the extensive data from her 40-year study, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a pioneering zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.

Before Goodall's work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. Her discoveries revealed that chimpanzees eat meat, use tools, and have emotions and social systems similar to humans. They also have unique cultural traditions across Africa. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is considered the most authoritative work on chimpanzee research. Her long-term study in Gombe State, Nigeria, is seen as one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world, according to biologist Stephen Jay Gould. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. At five years old, in the autumn of 1939, she disappeared one afternoon. The police and neighbors searched for her, and she reappeared at dusk with straw in her hair. She explained to her mother that she had been in a henhouse, hiding in the straw for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity foreshadowed her future as a biologist.

In our first hour-long chat, Shirley Ford shows off her talent by speaking in the voices of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV, cartoons, and even those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I just did a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say lots of medical terms.’ Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,’ she says. ‘But it’s more than that. You have to make the script come alive for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for the publicity, but often they don’t get the parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a typical acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV ads. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the studio manager suggested I try out for a rabbit in a cartoon soundtrack. It seemed silly – I didn’t study drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, surprisingly, got a major role.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often voice young boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and lots of paperwork, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the highlight of a job that includes everything from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. ‘Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this profession help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you’re talking – that makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that specialize in helping voiceover artists create them.’ She claims she reached the top of her profession through persistence as much as natural talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone thinking about a voiceover career, Shirley suggests attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a passion for human sound is crucial, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a particular kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a dream job for many kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more practical careers, like becoming a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do it. Most cartoonists have wanted to do it for a long time. In my case, I loved comic strips as a child, contributed to school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons on local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was earning enough to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are minimal, but it's still a challenging job. You shouldn't try to become a cartoonist unless you can't imagine doing anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't turn down work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of cartooning? There was a time when many cartoonists could find steady work with newspapers and magazines. But those days are mostly over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create and sell your work. Cartoonists with average talent but good business skills often do better than artistic geniuses who lack those skills. I'm surprised by how many people are afraid someone will steal their ideas, even if they've never sold a cartoon. Some are so worried they won't let anyone see their work! To protect your work legally, just draw a 'c' for 'copyright,' circle it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it's more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving house and decided to get rid of some things. One of those things was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to get rid of this guitar? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, "You're not just going to throw that away, are you?" I said I was, but I already felt a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways, but I felt a deep regret for years afterward.

Then, a few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. The email was from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back and used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so emotional. I would have paid anything, but his price was fair. I had forgotten my dad's habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have found this whole situation funny.

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s when it was very popular. I loved its calming sound, but I didn't make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn't need to be a great musician to be a rock star. When I got my guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. The guitar felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I felt the need to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder. My fingers remembered the chords, even though I couldn't draw them. My fingertips felt the familiar pain of pressing the strings.

The electric guitar isn't really a solo instrument, so now that I'm learning it again, I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are others my age with similar stories. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There's been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," which is about people who can't sleep, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Insomniacs, who I interviewed many of, know how crucial sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. Those who struggle to sleep often understand its importance the most. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? They haven't been talked about much. We often lose dreams, especially when we wake up early and miss the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, the stage rich in dreams. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years dreaming. When people are deprived of REM, they experience more intense REM sleep the next night, suggesting dreams have a purpose. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding the mind. However, later research didn't support this idea, and the study of dreams shifted to their physical origins. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than others. He concluded that dream use increases with interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams since films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Doesn't everyone—teachers, software designers, politicians—need to think creatively? Stickgold says dreams help us combine ideas in new, surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create combinations that break our usual thinking habits. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They "ignore the obvious and put together things that make a kind of crazy unexpected sense... This is what creativity is," says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you barely remember, seems to give some kind of fluency, fuel for thought. On those days, words and images come so quickly that my fingers can hardly keep up. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly as we deal with relationships with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. In her studio, which has a stunning sea view, you see empty frames on the walls alongside photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading figure in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate the richness of early-20th century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Surprisingly, she doesn't keep any of her own work. "As soon as I finish them, they go," she says. Susie is in high demand. Over her 30-year career as a copyist artist, she has recreated works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that even art experts can mistake them for the originals. While the originals could sell for millions, her copies sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie keeps her clients' identities mostly private, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but for others, status is important. One celebrity likes to show off his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh'. "Many famous people pass off my copies as originals," she says. "That's their choice." Some collectors save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying Susie's copy. Susie is always honest about her work. She makes her reproductions look as authentic as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. Passing off a copy as an original is illegal, and although she knows people who have profited from it, she has never been tempted. Those who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie isn't wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and risking her reputation doesn't make sense. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. It was a good foundation for her current work and sparked her love for plants, though it was hard to live on. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets but is glad to have found something more financially rewarding. When young artists ask for advice, Susie emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to achieve her skills. Her training allows her to do anything from drawing plants to making perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces to reproducing 20th-century abstract art. She now focuses on French impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas as her favorites. Susie notes that people often think modern art is simple, almost like child's play. For example, impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also very precise. This combination is challenging to master. Given her talent, it's surprising that Susie doesn't create her own original art. Isn't art about self-expression? And could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She explains that her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and it provides a good living. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—good, but not exceptional. Perhaps it's like living on simple food after a lifetime of gourmet meals. Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest on it. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a unique connection with the boats that took her around the world, working in perfect harmony with them. Once back on land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly longed to return to the ocean, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop race around the world, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was a small, cramped space where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how she meticulously planned everything, down to the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial. She proudly displayed her stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her attention to detail in maintaining the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. This experience made her think differently and realize things she hadn't considered before. Seeing abandoned whaling stations felt like a warning about how we take resources and move on. When I met Ellen at her office, she had just finished a heated conference call. She explained why urgent action is needed to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways not to use them up," she said. Initially, her message was about using less, but she later focused on re-using, like promoting reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the past three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she admits, "but I love learning. The current situation became something I couldn't ignore. Sailing seemed selfish in comparison. This is about finding how my voice can be most useful. It really matters."

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It defines who I am. At sea, you are connected to everything around you, focused on records, practicalities, and survival. My new message isn't as simple as saying, 'I'm going to be the fastest around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I've done before."

Jordan Romero, at 13, aims to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If successful, he could become a very famous teenager. With many young people spending time on computers and games, he wants to inspire them to explore the outdoors. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen, and they call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is part of a bigger goal: if Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest to climb the Seven Summits, the highest peaks on each continent. Few achieve this before 30. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might complete this before turning 20.

Many experienced Everest climbers doubt the wisdom of a 13-year-old attempting the climb. They agree a young climber might be physically strong but question if a teenager has the emotional strength and experience needed for safe climbing. The Romeros are aware of these concerns. Paul says, ‘I know there’s criticism, but I can’t focus on it. We think about risks, but our climbing experience helps. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He’s becoming strong and mature.’

There’s also the question of Jordan’s motivation. Is it his father’s ambition pushing him? Paul insists it’s not about him seeking fame through his son. They decided to pursue the goal now rather than later. They regularly check with Jordan to ensure he remains motivated. When asked what he enjoys about the challenge, Jordan says, ‘I just focus on achieving my goal.’

In the past, few cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain. Now, every adventure is shared online, turning climbs into record-setting challenges. This creates a dilemma for Jordan. To inspire others, he must engage with the media, blog, and give interviews. He needs to offer something spectacular, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, ‘If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we’ll end this project and head to the gym.’

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they're not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but even my classmates aren't very familiar with classical music. If you don't know the composers, you're unlikely to buy their music. For classical music fans, the statistics are disappointing. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells just 300 copies. It's hard to believe, but true. So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people often blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The simple fact is that classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who love classical concerts, but they're rare. Even though I'm a musician and play in an orchestra, I'm not a huge classical music fan. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm, with many mood changes, can be challenging for us. We like things fast. Experts say we struggle to focus for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop songs also have lyrics that appeal more to teenagers than long classical pieces without words. The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online instantly, but we rarely choose classical. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says classical concert audiences have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many teenagers are in those audiences. In my orchestra, we play classical music in various places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why more people like classical concerts as they get older, but I do know that if teenagers' parents love something, they often avoid it. Some blame schools for teenagers' lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are eager to play in school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy performing classical music, but it's not their first choice for listening. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you regret that I’m here," she said to the school, with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the car on the other side and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among trees on a wooded hillside; it seemed confusing at first. Then she noticed the signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother replied. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved between the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of trailing behind like a dog," Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t really expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll probably be expelled soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and headed towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was a nice old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. Bonnie always treated horses well. She could see they were well cared for. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, gently touching its nose. The next horse caught her attention. "You’re the best one here!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He seemed lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick, according to the sign above his stall. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They must be nearby." Bonnie was thrilled to find the room with the riding equipment unlocked. She was so focused on saddling Maverick that she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she saw. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m not joking, because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She urged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think we could be great friends," she confided. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he’d be a good jumper.

I've met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. At just 15 years old, the Australian has already released several successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up performing on stage for thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven." He remembers how it all started. "But back then, I was swimming every day and surfing. Those were the things that mattered more to me; I had my life planned out and plenty to keep me busy. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted a few videos online." These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans left comments online, asking for more videos on their social media. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The response was overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer, training hard with top coaches and focusing on his sport. But then record labels showed interest, and he faced a tough decision: stay in Australia and continue swimming, or take a big risk by signing a record deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was very hard for me—especially at such a young age—to choose a career. Can you imagine, at 12 or 13, trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I'm kind of the quiet kid," he says, recalling their shocked reactions. "I'm very modest, and I think it's important to stay that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn't directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody believes it's important to have a close group of great people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, everyone has moments of doubt. "Sometimes when I'm alone, I think, 'How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?' My little brother is eight, traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn't have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about how that affects him, but my family always reassures me that they're here to support and encourage me in everything I do." Success, in any career, comes from being willing to say "yes" to your big opportunity, even when it's a bit scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be visiting countries I never thought I'd see and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans—it's like something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won't last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbag wall, which was there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags into place. Last week, I worked long hours with most of the town's adults, showing I could handle it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and solid ice downstream. As I changed out of my pyjamas and into my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn't recognize him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain—a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It's more special to me than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. Plus, I have his diary from that journey, which I keep under my pillow and read before bed. I patted the chain and headed to the kitchen. "Morning, Rex," Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. "You're up early for a Saturday. I'll make brunch after your training. Be careful." "Thanks, Mom." I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. "Watch where you're going!" he shouted. "Where are you off to?" "Sorry, Grandpa. I'm going kayaking." As if my wetsuit didn't make that clear. As if he didn't see me kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore his temper, but it's getting harder. "Why train? You didn't win the competition," he said. His words stung, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. Mom appeared with a sympathetic smile. "Don't mind him. He's..." "...not himself right now," I finished for her. I didn't say he's always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a kid, he was my hero—ever since he showed me his photos in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang in his room, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don't go in there anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. Yet, a part of me still wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. "At least he's coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your dedication, even on cold days!" I smiled back as I peeled my banana. "It'll be warmer in South America," I said. "If I find sponsors for my expedition." She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. In the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study, where an unframed painting leaned against the wall. It was clearly Grandpa's work, but different from anything he had done before and obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the painting. It featured a river that dominated the scene; it wasn't a river she recognized and might not even be real, perhaps just a fantasy. The picture was strange and shapeless, yet beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green that the eye almost missed, as it was drawn into the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice—too casual, too detached—that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others interpret them if they could. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed to have a strange importance to her, though she couldn't say why. And there was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it—for him to be so specific. Still, he hasn't finished it yet, so maybe he'll add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't resist. It's such an unusual picture, especially having a name. I suppose you can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to waste time telling every idiot..." "Ignoramus, he said." "...every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone who came along, they'd never get any work done. And he said..." Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually to say the muse wasn't being kind to him that day, or that he'd have to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on, or something like that. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human being. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

This morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that's what happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I'll cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm quite unlucky that way. 

What I was actually trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute—small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and tiny glass-panelled doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet, so I was thrilled when she gave it to me. But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it needs to stand in a corner. 

I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But since Angela is only fifteen, I'll be in my small room for a while. I don't mind; I like my cosy little bedroom. It's like a nest, with a sloping roof and a window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only take a couple of centimetres off the bottom... 

Then it hit me. If I couldn't cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he's always telling us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in a house, secretly taking things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation, I knew it would be challenging to meet fans' expectations. People who love the book have strong opinions about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' perspective, not the humans', which made filming more complex. The most important thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when filming them, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. To capture the Borrowers' view, the crew had to film from no higher than 15 centimeters off the ground, which wore out a lot of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. A big challenge was making the shadows look right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US director George Lucas called to ask how we did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry giant items like scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift, often making the crew laugh. In one scene, the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors were swept down a tunnel with hoses and found it so scary they didn't have to act. Getting the costumes right was important to me, and other directors have struggled with this. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend, and she couldn't sit during breaks or take the dress off because it was sewn on each morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don't think they appreciated my attention to detail! Most scenes away from the Borrowers' home were shot with actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren't accurate, but they worked. The budget didn't allow for special effects studio time during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren't there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, people pretending to be friends, and the requests for free tickets to my dad's concerts. "Everything's going to be fine," I reassure her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted—to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the band is here for recording, we're staying permanently. I chose this school because I want to meet regular kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal. 

I walk into the school's main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the secretary. "Name?" she asks, not very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she mishears, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused but types "McGraw" on her keyboard. Luckily, few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it's printing," she says, then hands me the schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great, I like English. I'll be late, though. It's in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night to avoid looking lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already calling roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles, checking out my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. Perfect, no one will suspect anything! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oops, maybe not so normal. "Thanks," I reply. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says uncertainly. "Here." She smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After discussing the books we'll read this year, she lets us socialize. All teachers should do this. "So why'd you move here?" my new friend asks. I have options. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. A little lie works better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But I can pretend to be normal for now. "He's an artist," I say, fiddling with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I'm Becca, by the way." And she doesn't seem to care. Perfect.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do a lot: be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what being a teenager in America is like now. Teenagers can't just go to school and be average; they need to stand out. Being average is not enough, and not having big ambitions is seen as laziness. 

Many adults don't realize how much pressure teenagers face today. They have lots of homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life. Teenager Kristen Loose explains this pressure. Despite these challenges, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes describe teenagers as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might fit these descriptions, it's not fair to label the entire generation this way.

Loose points out that people often think teenagers spend all their time watching TV or on their phones. She disagrees, saying that while she keeps her phone close, it's not just for fun. It's a tool that helps teenagers manage their busy lives. Today, students are expected to be connected to the world and reachable at all times, which can seem like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can work anywhere, even on the go. Schoolwork and activities now demand attention around the clock, adding to the stress of already busy teens.

Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight, filled with school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20% of teens get enough sleep, and 28% admitted to falling asleep in school at least once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time a week, which isn't much out of 168 hours. She doesn't waste this time on social media or TV but focuses on volunteering. Olsen believes the stereotype of teenagers is that they only care about themselves, but she enjoys volunteering and making a positive impact in her community.

In the future, the stereotype of teenagers might change, but they will continue to challenge it and push the world forward. A new generation of students will keep making a difference, even before they finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. This group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. Their project is a mix of science and adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These occur when a rock or metal piece enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside was a camera, an altitude instrument, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers were on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, was used to inflate the balloon, which grew to the size of a small car. An older boy had driven seven hours to get the gas. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For these kids, such efforts are normal. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chanted, and the balloon began to rise. Some ran and tracked it with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There was a quiet sense of wonder. Then the balloon vanished into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets on the mountainside, looking at the clear sky, just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I saw a boy get into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ a girl said softly. ‘I know,’ whispered another. A meteor shot across the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon expands until it bursts. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. The area around Bishop is mostly uninhabited, so the lunch box usually lands in remote places. ‘Recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, noting they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To reach it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘These students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to them.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It was a bit disappointing, but it was a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work over mountains. And it was another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. Her interest began by chance when she helped her younger brother with a science project. She found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology, which fascinated her and made her realize she wanted to pursue it. At that time, Palaeontology wasn't a common career choice for young people. Chloe recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. She was nervous about meeting him, worried he might find her annoying, but he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

Chloe discusses how palaeontologists are portrayed in movies and TV shows. Films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She finds the portrayal of palaeontologists as either eccentric geniuses or geeky losers misleading. Movies don't accurately show the reality of their work. Chloe's job involves digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific publications. She also believes in communicating scientific findings to the public, especially to young people, to clear up misunderstandings about science and inspire interest in the natural world.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she advised on the accuracy of the dinosaurs portrayed. The program succeeded in attracting audiences of all ages because it depicted dinosaurs more accurately than movies like Jurassic Park. Chloe believes dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. They remind us that there is still much to learn and discover, and Palaeontology offers a form of time travel.

I'm going to say this just once: when you're on a car trip with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not "there yet," even as you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" And really, once you arrive, it's not "there" anymore; it's "here." So if you think you might be "there," you should ask, "Are we here yet?" And no one wants to be "there" more than the parents who keep hearing that question during long car rides. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing expected of you? You can watch DVDs you haven't seen, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, there's mom or dad, ready to hand out juice boxes and cookies, or change the radio station and temperature as needed – basically, making sure everything goes smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying – like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. What? He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it's his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's all over my space, and a fight starts. The driver and co-pilot reach back to separate us as the car speeds up and swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a bit. The beautiful scenery continues to pass by. Soon after, I'm trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the car isn't going fast, and the window isn't open. Where's it coming from? My brother is next to me, quietly blowing air on me. He's on his side, not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. Just breathing? What's the problem with that? The anger builds. Tim gets yelled at, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again – for now. Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us kids in the back seat. For example, when we ask, "Are we there yet?" he often says, "Yup. We're here. Get out of the car." "But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour." "Oh, well, then maybe we're not there yet." That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move as far away as they can from the kids who have been bothering them for hours. So remember: if mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you're not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where customers can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: "With so much technology, everyone is busy on their phones. We wanted to bring people together without screens. It's natural for us to connect and communicate."

The games at their café are called 'Eurogames,' known for gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged. This idea evolved into 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. Pandemic, a Eurogame by North American designer Matt Leacock, is a popular example where players work together to solve global issues. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame based on Lord of the Rings. He recalls playing it with friends and feeling a range of emotions, wanting to create a similar experience.

Leacock's love for board games started in childhood, despite often feeling disappointed by them. With his uncle's help, he began redesigning games to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its sequel added more storytelling, similar to video games, where characters develop and the world changes.

Interestingly, the growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Video games have made playing games more common, as many people now play games on their smartphones. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, notes that video and board games have learned from each other, and more people are open to playing games now.

Initially, video games offered social interaction in arcades or through multiplayer games at home. But as multiplayer games moved online, players became physically distant. This led some people to seek games they could play in person with others. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just entertainment. In our online world, these games offer a way to connect in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has been behind some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His journey shows why persistence is crucial in the music industry, even if your career starts with setbacks. Jamie's mother, a talented singer, introduced him to the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for older audiences, which influenced his musical tastes. He didn't hear a modern song until he was 12. Around that time, he had to choose between pursuing tennis, which he played at a national level, and music, as he spent his school lunchtimes playing piano. Although he was good at tennis, he realized it wasn't his passion. At 17, he left school to pursue music. He formed a duo with a friend who was a decent guitarist but not as committed to a music career. Jamie told his parents about his dream, explaining that he wrote lyrics during economics classes and played piano while others played outside. His father gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would need to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed by a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he parted ways with his friend. Ultimately, Jamie found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he switched to another to release a new album, but fame didn't come. He felt he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time as an artist, but as a songwriter, he was in the right place. Writing for others became his strength. Jamie believes he is one of the main writers UK labels rely on to help new artists start their careers. He sometimes explains to these artists that aiming for chart success is nothing to be ashamed of. He encourages them to create songs they love that also have the potential to sell well. Jamie is refreshingly honest about wanting to write hit songs. He isn't arrogant; he simply knows he has a talent for writing number-one hits. Instead of worrying about others' opinions, he focuses on his goal. When he works with someone in the studio, he aims to create music that can succeed globally and become classic modern pop songs.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He's very famous online but might be unknown to people who don't watch videos of bike stunts. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist,' which means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. When I met him for an interview at a BMX park, many local boys and even older people recognized him and called him a 'legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed with them. I was impressed by his bravery and creativity, even though I was skeptical at first. 

Tony explained each stunt before doing it, and I often doubted he could succeed. But he always did, though he seemed indifferent to my praise. Despite his online fame, Tony doesn't enjoy being a celebrity. He finds it hard to engage socially and prefers doing things rather than talking about them. This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. He acknowledges that this technology allows him to make a living from what would have been just a hobby in the past. 

From my experience interviewing top athletes, I've learned that two key factors turn a passionate child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to overcome emotional setbacks. These are often more important than talent and help athletes persist despite failures. In risky sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on relatively easy obstacles but kept trying until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he's reckless. Tony responds that these critics don't understand the sport and haven't ridden a trials bike. They don't know the technical details or that he gets expert advice to minimize risks. Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He believes it's important to be aware of dangers. He divides people into those who can't overcome fear and those who can. He feels fear but finds a way to move past it. He's not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning and preparing. Before a new stunt, he rides around to get in the right mindset. He knows he must fully commit to succeed.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on several dangerous challenges for charity, like running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge involved walking on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, just a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she quickly learned that high-wire walking was very different. "The training was a shock," Helen said. "I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she admitted afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole using skis, a kite, and a bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it for a holiday trip to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set off in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst experience was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel bed with a serious fever and no medicine. He didn’t have money for hospital bills or to return home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that lets us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their population has decreased significantly, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have a lot of information about their daytime activities, but nothing about what they do at night because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat based on our findings. The work is challenging. There are four of us, each working six hours a day. We have studied ducks in various locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and record every duck I see. The weather has been difficult—some nights are mild, but more often it's wet. It's so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We've only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Despite the challenges, I enjoy it, especially compared to what summer will bring—long hours in a lab analyzing our results. It will be tough to be indoors, but it's necessary. I wouldn't change this experience for anything!

Whenever I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is crucial to ensure that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from the company I work for. Every week, I get samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, and spend time selecting the best ones for our chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues, which makes them happy! My kitchen is filled with machines and ingredients for experimenting. It's great to have a private space to retreat to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm at our food lab, and other times I'm traveling abroad to buy raw materials. This can be challenging since I have a young family. However, I love the variety and unpredictability of the job, although the chocolate itself is still my favorite part! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things such as balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, "For a circus career, performers need to avoid repeating the same acts – it's important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to succeed in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great aspect is the friendship with other performers and the opportunity to learn from them. Being fit is also crucial – circus artists, like athletes, train daily to stay strong. Training is very important, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work a few months each year. But the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only perform while you're young, and then you need to think about other options." The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started businesses worldwide and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, that it's not a profession for making money! "The work usually means not having a regular salary. It's also competitive – but a lot of fun!"

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you've probably heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't good enough to be lead singers, but that's not true. They often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the true stars of the music industry! "What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing," she says. "It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job!" "Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. There's often no sheet music to follow. I'll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, plus an orchestra. I was terrified because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough already." "One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always know which musical range suits the female voice best. By listening to me perform their song, they can figure out how to improve it."

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful company selling 'satchels,' which are traditional school bags. These bags are now sold in famous stores and are popular with celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning, instead of just going with her first thought. Once she chose satchels, not everyone supported her decision. Julie recalls, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had no career experience but had a natural talent for business. The design inspiration came from children's storybooks. Although Julie wasn't familiar with fashion blogs, they played a crucial role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would mention them in their blogs. They did, and interest grew, as did the speed of production. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is spotted with a satchel. While other companies spend on online ads, she uses the internet community for fresh style ideas, keeping her products innovative. There was a tough time when another company copied her design to sell similar bags. As a result, she now ensures she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices, where people love working. There's a new factory now, and while the building is important, it's the team that makes it special.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose how to spend their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a talented swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with her schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky found it exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. At 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky explained, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it all – and when the excitement fades, there’s no point. Fortunately, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, bringing young people together as part of a larger group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people doubt whether celebrity support is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it for their own publicity, which can overshadow the charity’s real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Ana Ronson, a singer-songwriter, grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but music was always present at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. Ana first sang in front of an audience at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to build her confidence. After some time in the club, Ana sang with 50 other students at a concert and felt happy doing it. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, "Falling Stars," in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she took a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Although she was the youngest in the class, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher ignored her ideas, which inspired her to write "Something to Say" about her frustration. She posted the song online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled across Ireland to invite her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn't know the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. Joss assured her this wouldn't happen, and soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and the event was a great success. Ana prefers writing songs about difficult times rather than when life is good because she feels there's more to express. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes fans enjoy her music, her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an incredible trip. I joined a guided group tour by boat along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry's idea. Like me, he's a journalist, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. Harry loves boats, but that's not something we have in common. However, I had always wanted to visit that area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew our great-grandparents had lived there before moving to Europe, so I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we planned to visit. Fortunately, the weather forecast predicted calm seas for when we would be there. I was busy with work and didn't have much time to think about the trip preparations. But Harry assured me he had taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying.

Once we arrived in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off.
