The guide told us that very few people lived along that coast, and indeed, the only other living creatures we saw on the first morning were dolphins and birds. There were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see them, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of amazing, colorful fish, many of which I didn't recognize. It was wonderful not to worry about time passing. We always made sure to have lunch and dinner, which we cooked together over campfires. Each evening, when we finally fell asleep on the boats, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life!

When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends if I stayed. I was also excited to share our adventures with everyone at home!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. As a kid, I often went to watch his games. You might think this would make me love basketball, but it actually had the opposite effect. I enjoyed bragging to my friends about how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually brought a book to read instead of watching the games. 

When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager but was already two meters tall. Seeing my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session but felt I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I did. It took some convincing, but a few weeks later, I played against another school. Having my parents watch made me nervous, but it turned out fine in the end.

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did well, even joining an adult team. At fifteen, I moved to a special sports academy in the USA. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn't enjoy being far from my parents at first. Back home, I didn't have much time for friends because of training, so that part wasn't new. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly.

I turned professional at eighteen, three years after moving to the USA. I had been taller than most professional players since I was fifteen, but I was too light for my height, so I had to work on that. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism in college and needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After looking at different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my hometown, Chicago, USA. This job involved showing visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see my city through the eyes of tourists, making it feel new every time! After finishing my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but I learned that to get a license, I needed to know much more than I already did. Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including its architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent guide. Tour guiding isn't just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. You also need to be entertaining, tell interesting stories, and adapt to changes, like if a place is unexpectedly closed or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organized tour without hearing about problems. I need to ensure visitors are happy with my tours because they might leave reviews online. Good reviews are crucial as they attract more customers. That's why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. My enthusiasm and energy usually result in very good reviews, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I'm 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Even though Josie is five years younger than me, we get along quite well. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were much older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first time doing something like this. However, we didn't need to worry. 

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it really hard, but seeing the elephants enjoy their food made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I found this very fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants! 

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a room, so it was a bit cramped, but that was our choice because Josie didn't want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and vegetarian, which was great since neither of us likes meat. After dinner, we spent the evenings talking and playing games with the other volunteers and staff.

Now that we're back in the UK, Josie doesn't talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I'm not sure she's being completely honest. I think she might be a bit upset with herself for not making the most of her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she looks back, she realizes how lucky she was to have gone. Maybe she'll return one day—I definitely will!

I'm Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We don't just sell flowers to people for their homes or as gifts; we have a variety of customers. Hotels and offices often want flowers for their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for business photo shoots. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was really proud of it.

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I'm crazy, but I love what I do. It's often cold and dark, but that's expected at that hour, so it doesn't bother me. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were choosing for myself, I'd probably only pick pink ones because it's my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like and what customers want can be different. Not all flowers are available year-round, so sometimes I can't find exactly what customers want.

I don't enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it's necessary. Flowers aren't cheap, so I have to get the best price I can. Back at the shop, we check customer orders and arrange the flowers I've bought. Then we create bouquets and calculate the costs. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy figuring out how to make the nicest arrangements within a customer's budget. That's part of selling, and I wouldn't want any other job!

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films, including many for kids on weekends. It's close to where I live. However, a year ago, I felt something was missing – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, with two friends, I started a film club! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we pick a different location in the city each month. For instance, we once used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the atmosphere perfect for the film, and it was amazing! Some places we use are even free because the owners earn money by selling snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We’re happy just to cover our costs – we’re not aiming to make a profit. Each time we show a film, things get a bit easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We also know how many tickets we've sold because everything is online, so we don't worry about empty seats anymore! There’s still a lot to do, but when people of all ages tell us they had a great experience, it’s wonderful. Our website has been very helpful, and we’re now in touch with other film clubs across the country. We’ve visited them to see how they operate, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We’ve also started a blog because most people now look online for film information instead of reading local paper reviews. We’ve tried putting up posters in cafés too. However, nothing beats word of mouth – people recommending us to their friends. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film – last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed.

As a child, taking photographs was my favorite activity. When I turned 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I decided to do something special. I started a personal project: taking one photograph every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but it seemed like a great idea to me, so I began. After a few weeks, I uploaded my photos to a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and share my work with others. I was surprised to find that people liked my perspective and photography style. I enjoyed capturing a variety of subjects. Someone suggested that my project would be better if all the photos had a common theme. I agreed and focused on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were in black and white, which was different from what other young photographers were doing, as they mostly used color. I sometimes doubted my project and almost gave up several times. However, I trusted my instincts and became more confident in my style and choices. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher, who told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some of my photos for fun. I’ll never forget when the judges announced I had won first prize; I was thrilled because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized my photography might be good enough for a professional career. Now, I have my own photography studio and have never regretted my career choice.

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because they offered activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking, which I had never tried before. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities to push yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called 'leaders'. When you finish each level, you receive a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested I help organize activities at a local children's club for two hours a week as my first challenge. I was unsure about this because I had been a member of that club when I was eight and had trouble making friends. I was shy, and the other kids already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to accept the challenge because I wanted to earn my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I found myself wanting to spend all my free time at the children's club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. After completing the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed strong relationships with the children. Now, I volunteer there for about four hours a week and always look forward to it. 

Thanks to my experience at the children's club, I have decided that after finishing school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. This was not something I had considered before joining the club. In fact, I had never thought about my future career, and youth work had never crossed my mind. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have earned several other NYC certificates now, including one for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA, and started snowboarding when I was eight. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, and my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was young and hadn't thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I did well. After that, I quickly grew to love the sport and got better at it. I started competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my passion for competing and winning has only grown stronger, which motivates me to push myself. I like not having a fixed plan, and sometimes it works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn't sure I would try the jumps that got me this score until I started. That success boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and studying since there's no snow. I train every day, but it's nice not to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend a lot of time with friends, which helps me cope with not being able to snowboard. I have to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I also want to have another option in case I don't succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I'm considering becoming a doctor if I can balance it with my active lifestyle. I can't imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can't do it forever.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had and didn't think about the future. For instance, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it only if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I'm grateful to my parents for this because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't enjoy it much. My parents suggested I start my own small business instead. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it. I found it surprisingly easy, even though it looked complicated when I watched Mum. My friends thought it was boring, but I was excited about it. Mum showed me how to make beautiful things at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewelry to friends and family. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. I needed to know if they were good enough for the public, so I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists visit where I live, and they bought a lot of my jewelry to take home as gifts. Soon, we got calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many employees, but it was just the two of us at a market stall! That's when I realized it could work, and it was time to create a website. Since then, I've made thousands of pounds through my business, mostly online, although we still have our stall too. It's been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called "Being Amelia," which became a bestseller. The book is partly inspired by Janine's own life. In an interview, Janine explained that because her father's job required the family to move frequently, she became skilled at making new friends. This experience helped her write about Amelia, the main character, adjusting to a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia's home life, especially her interactions with her older brother. Since Janine is an only child, she had to use her imagination to write those parts.

Janine began writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to start writing. The year before, she had won first prize in a short story competition on a young writers' website. This success made the publishing company eager to read "Being Amelia" when she sent it to them. They loved it, and a year later, the book was available in stores.

A review of "Being Amelia" notes that even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters in the story face real challenges, which makes them believable to readers. The reviewer also mentions that despite Janine's young age and the book's short length, she has proven to be a better writer than many bestselling authors.

Janine is still adjusting to her fame as a writer. She said, "At first, I hid when people recognized me on the street, but now it's OK. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, spending time with friends always gives me new ideas to write about!"

I live in a house surrounded by beautiful countryside in Scotland. I've always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby—birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural environment. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different species apart and find the best places to see them. It was amazing, and after returning home, I joined a local young birdwatchers' club. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I've almost reached that because, on family holidays abroad, I've had the chance to see birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I've been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I thought I might see my 200th species. I wasn't too disappointed when it didn't happen, though, as I've learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it fascinating and commented on it. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn't feel nervous until just before they introduced me and I walked onto the stage. I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching me! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might even do another one next year! I'm lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually plenty of birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn't have to cost much money.

I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a decent player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought the same would happen with football. But it didn’t. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and a referee noticed I was a promising player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. She was impressed and invited me to join her club. I couldn’t believe it at first—I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But I started training regularly with a big club when I was just 13. I improved a lot after that. Even so, some people doubted I’d become a star player, which made me a bit upset. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want the other players to blame me if we lost. By pure luck, I scored the winning goal. Despite the large crowd, I could clearly hear my coach cheering me on, and after the match, the team carried me around the pitch. It was fantastic! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals. Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to talk to other players in my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to believe they could play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach’s advice to me—you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few bad times, though, so I’ve been lucky!

In recent years, both in the UK and internationally, there has been a significant shift in further and higher education to involve students in research early in their studies. This change acknowledges that research is not just for renowned scholars or scientists at prestigious universities. Instead, research is a fundamental way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are valuable not only in academics but also in the workplace, as they help us think critically about the world and our work. As a student, you contribute to knowledge by creating it, not just by learning and repeating it. This involves asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are at the heart of research.

Research can range from groundbreaking, complex studies by highly trained experts to everyday inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questioning. Most students have engaged in some form of research, whether in school projects or everyday tasks like planning a holiday or fixing things at home. In college and higher education, having an enquiring mind, identifying problems, critically evaluating information, and forming your own ideas are expected learning activities.

Some students might find this challenging, especially if they come from educational backgrounds where knowledge is seen as fixed and authority figures are not questioned. However, in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authority is encouraged. This approach might seem daunting, but critical thinking is crucial in research. We need to engage with others' research, think critically about it, and test its validity. It's important not to accept information blindly but to assess whether it is logical, reasoned, and supported by evidence.

Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity. In the 18th century, London coffee houses were places where people discussed topics like chemistry and politics. In modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were where artist Pablo Picasso talked about modern art. However, living in a city is not always easy. Those same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While cities are creative hubs, they can also be overwhelming and unnatural. 

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. It's known that city life is tiring, but new research shows that it can also dull our thinking. One major issue is the lack of nature, which is surprisingly good for our brains. Studies show that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even brief views of nature can improve brain function because they offer a mental break from the busy city life.

This research is timely because, for the first time in history, most people live in cities. Instead of open spaces, we are packed into concrete jungles with millions of strangers. These unnatural environments affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. Walking down a busy city street requires our brains to manage many distractions, like other pedestrians and traffic. This constant need to focus drains our mental energy because the brain has to decide what to pay attention to and what to ignore.

In contrast, natural settings don't demand as much mental effort. This concept is called attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can restore our attention. Nature captures our attention without causing stress, unlike city noises like police sirens. This allows our minds to relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied these effects, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the impact of city life and sought ways to bring nature into urban areas. Parks like Central Park in New York offer city dwellers a break from urban life. A well-designed park can quickly improve brain function. While people try various methods to boost cognitive performance, like energy drinks or office redesigns, simply walking in nature seems to be more effective.

Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Even in the digital age, they remain centers of intellectual life. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that challenge our attention, like crowded streets, also promote innovation. The concentration of social interactions in cities drives creativity. Just as 18th-century London was a hub of intellectual breakthroughs, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are centers of technological innovation. Less crowded cities might produce less innovation over time.

The challenge is to reduce the psychological stress of city life while keeping its benefits. After all, there are times when people crave the excitement of the city over the calm of nature.

Where should we look for the mind? It might seem obvious to say that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques to support this idea. However, I believe the study of the mind shouldn't be limited to just the brain. There is plenty of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects and tools also play a role in human thinking. Archaeology shows us that items like stone tools, jewelry, engravings, clay tokens, and writing systems have been important in human evolution and shaping the mind. So, I propose that what is outside the head might still be part of the mind.

It's easy to see why people equate the mind with the brain. Most of our knowledge about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their usual surroundings. This approach makes sense for neuroscientists because of the limitations of brain-scanning machines. However, it often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I don't deny the importance of the brain in cognition, but I suggest that the mind extends beyond the brain into culture and the material world.

This is where my theory, Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET explores how objects become extensions of our minds, like when we use clay to make numbers or a stone to create a tool. It also looks at how these interactions have changed over time and what they mean for our thinking. This approach offers new insights into what minds are and how they are shaped by the things around us.

Consider a blind person using a stick. Where does their sense of self begin? The stick becomes part of their body, showing how minds and objects can be continuous. This example also highlights the flexibility of the human mind: the stick helps the blind person turn touch into sight. The brain treats the stick as part of the body, reminding us that human intelligence is adaptable and can incorporate new technologies.

I see the human mind as an ongoing project, always evolving. Throughout history, from early stone tools to the internet, tools have served as pathways for exploration and understanding, not just boundaries. Unlike a monkey using a stick to get food, humans use tools to satisfy our curiosity. This unique human trait explains why we create things and how those things, in turn, shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and change as they interact with the material world.

I want to emphasize the role of material objects in shaping our cognition. MET provides a new way to understand how different forms of material culture, from ancient tools to modern technology, have defined and transformed our thinking. While "mind-changing technology" might sound futuristic, humans have been using it since our species first evolved.

Photography has significantly changed how we understand the world and has greatly influenced civilization, especially in the United States. In the U.S., photography quickly became a part of culture at all levels, from practical and scientific uses to industrial and artistic ones. It also opened up new forms of entertainment. Historians argue that photography might be the U.S.'s greatest contribution to the visual arts, as no other art form has been as influential. To fully appreciate its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Photography was appealing for several reasons. First, it was a mechanical process, which matched the growing enthusiasm for technology in the U.S., a country that embraced change. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made the world feel smaller by improving communication and travel, photography brought the wonders of the world into people's homes with stunning immediacy. Second, the camera became the preferred tool for representing oneself, as it could present an image for public view in a country where personal and national identities were constantly being created and recreated. Third, the camera was important for creating and preserving family memories, even if these were somewhat idealized. Lastly, the realistic nature of photographs aligned with the U.S. artists' tendency towards realism and depicting everyday life.

Photographs draw attention to what the photographer wants us to see, saying, "This, you should see!" Because they are made by a machine, photographs are records of events, people, and things, providing a sense of objectivity. However, since they are taken by individuals, they also carry a subjective point of view. We might think we understand a photograph because we recognize the subject, but photographic meaning is more complex. No image is presented without some context that influences our understanding, like a newspaper caption or its placement in a gallery.

To understand a photograph historically, we must consider its purpose and function within its cultural context: Why was it made? How was it first seen? The same image can appear in different places and times, changing its meaning each time. The camera's importance to artists was once a secret, but now it is widely recognized. Since the time of U.S. artist Andy Warhol, who used photographs in his art, artists have been incorporating photographs in various ways. Photographic vision has become an essential part of art, complementing painting and shaping our ideas of representation before the camera was invented.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have a mental life, so we have some understanding of what this means. However, even though we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains a complex concept. James, like most psychologists, was mainly interested in human psychology. He believed it involved basic elements: thoughts and feelings, a physical world existing in time and space, and a way of understanding these things. This understanding is personal and private, coming from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences, and may not always align with scientific facts. 

We often act as amateur psychologists when we give opinions on complex psychological topics, like whether brainwashing works, or when we explain why people behave in certain ways, such as feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems arise when people have different interpretations. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in a given situation. Psychologists help us distinguish between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts. 

Psychology, as defined by James, is about the mind or brain. Although psychologists study the brain, they don't fully understand its role in our hopes, fears, and behaviors. It's challenging to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about internal processes. Scientific facts should be objective and verifiable, but the mind's workings are not directly observable like an engine's. They must be inferred from behavior. Psychology is like solving a crossword puzzle, using clues derived from careful observation and analysis. 

Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and control or modify processes. Achieving these goals helps us understand our experiences and apply findings to improve lives. Psychological research has been useful in areas like teaching children to read, designing safer machines, and helping people communicate their feelings better. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation began only about 150 years ago. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to study mental structures. However, introspection has limitations, as it only reveals a small part of brain activity. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Modern psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of behavior rather than personal reflections.

In a warehouse in a typical business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum, owned by a company called GfK, showcases products that were taken off the market because almost no one wanted to buy them. Examples include A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola. Carol Sherry, who runs the museum, believes each product tells a sad story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved. Surprisingly, the museum is a successful business, which is unexpected because you might think companies would keep their own collections of failed products. However, many executives visit the museum because they often avoid thinking about their failures and don't keep samples of their unsuccessful products.

The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, began collecting a sample of every new product he could find in the 1960s, intending to create a 'reference library' of consumer products, not specifically failures. He discovered that most products fail, so his collection naturally became filled with unsuccessful ones.

Today's culture of optimism might explain why these failed products exist. Each product likely went through meetings where no one realized it was doomed. Even if they did, marketers might have continued investing in the product to force some sales and save face. Little effort is made to understand what went wrong, and people involved often avoid discussing the failures.

This focus on optimism is common in the growing 'self-help' industry, where 'positive visualization' is popular. The idea is that if you imagine things going well, they are more likely to do so. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot suggests that our brains might be wired to see the chances of success as higher than they are. Her research indicates that well-balanced people tend to have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence events, unlike those with depression.

Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have studied the effectiveness of 'positive fantasies about the future.' They found that thinking too much about how well things could go can actually reduce motivation to achieve goals. For example, people who imagined having a very successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our response to failure is influenced by our beliefs about ability. People with a 'fixed theory' mindset think ability is innate, while those with an 'incremental theory' believe it develops through effort and challenges. Fixed-theory individuals see failure as proof they lack ability, like a sports star who relies on being a 'natural' and doesn't practice enough. Incremental-theory individuals view failure as a sign they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger by being pushed to their limits. Having an incremental mindset is a happier way to live, regardless of success.

Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? We might think we know, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the traditional idea of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists are exploring what helps players perform at their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. Meanwhile, financial interests question if home advantage should matter at all, as players are paid well and should perform well anywhere. 

What about the fans? Would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their support is crucial for the team. Fans often think their cheering leads to goals, but they forget the times when their noise didn't result in success. 

However, one fan belief is supported by science: home fans influence referees. In an experiment, referees watched a match with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This matches real-life decisions, suggesting referees avoid making calls that would anger the home crowd.

Studies show that home advantage has decreased in major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home football teams in England won 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in luxury, and stadiums are more similar. Despite these changes, home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. This might be because baseball focuses more on individual matchups, while basketball relies on teamwork, which is boosted by playing at home.

Another factor could be players' testosterone levels, which are higher before home games. This might relate to a primal urge to defend home territory. In the recent Rugby World Cup, underdog teams playing at home won against stronger opponents, showing the power of home advantage. As one referee said, "It's the law of the jungle out there."

"The more I practise, the luckier I get," said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is famous in sports and valued by dedicated athletes and their coaches. The quote's origin is debated, with claims for other golfers of that time. Its meaning is also intriguing. Player didn't mean "lucky" literally; he was speaking ironically. His real message was, "The more I practise, the better I get." But how much better can one get through practice alone? This question is central to the nature-nurture debate in sports: is talent something you're born with, or can it be developed?

The debate isn't balanced; nurture, or practice, has been seen as more important than natural talent. This idea is largely based on psychologist Anders Ericsson's theory that becoming an expert in any field requires 10,000 hours of practice. This theory inspired books like Malcolm Gladwell's "Outliers" and others like "Talent Is Overrated" and "Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice." These books generally conclude that practice is the key to success, suggesting that 10,000 hours is enough to make anyone an expert.

However, in his book, Epstein argues that this isn't always true. He points out a flaw in studies on excellence: they often only look at successful people. Science is better at analyzing why an elite athlete succeeds after the fact. Epstein explores why some people have certain abilities while others don't, considering both innate traits and factors like environment, support, and determination.

Epstein's search for answers takes him worldwide, from Kenya to Sweden, the Caribbean to the Arctic, and even beyond human achievements. In Alaska, he learns that the key to winning the toughest sled dog race might be the husky dogs' drive and desire, suggesting a link between genetics and traits we think are voluntary. This challenges the idea that commitment and determination are purely choices. What if, as with the huskies, an individual's drive also has a genetic component?

These examples highlight the complexity of the topic. Epstein distinguishes between "hardware" (nature) and "software" (nurture) and agrees that in elite athletes, both are essential. He doesn't dismiss the importance of training or environment, suggesting that if Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. But Epstein also examines cases where genetics are crucial and can't be ignored. He also looks at race and gender issues, asking, "If only practice matters, why do we separate men and women in sports competitions?" Sometimes, the most obvious questions are the most important.

A recent international report shows that many children in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why this is happening. In her book, "Kith," she suggests that children are unhappy because they spend too much time indoors, in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature. This idea matches other discussions about modern childhood. A follow-up study found that many children would be happier if they could spend more time outside. People over 40 often remember their own childhoods fondly, recalling how they played outside freely, which they believe was healthier than the protected lives of today's children. However, they don't often realize that they are the ones who have created these protective environments for their kids, avoiding risks like playing in old sheds.

Griffiths' book includes strong arguments. She discusses how fear of outdoor dangers and consumerism keep children indoors, benefiting the toy and gadget industry. She also criticizes trends like giving medication to restless children or making them wear goggles for playground games. While some of these practices might be exaggerated, Griffiths expresses her views passionately. She also talks about childhood freedoms and restrictions, from fairy tales to school rules. Although her arguments are appealing, Griffiths sometimes takes them too far, ignoring important counter-arguments. At one point, she even compares modern treatment of children to a form of racism, which seems extreme.

Griffiths is a romantic when it comes to children, often seeing them in an idealized way. She believes children should have the freedom to explore and take risks, learning from small accidents to avoid bigger ones later. However, she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are "the right size." Also, not all children may want the adventurous life she describes. Some children are naturally timid and prefer staying at home. Perhaps the real issue is forcing all children into the same mold, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I'm a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I've spent a lot of time in school. I'm good at solving problems in my work and life, but this isn't because of my schooling. Most life problems can't be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play, and those with more to learn play the most. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how mammals, including humans, have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, moral lives can't be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is crucial for economic success. We don't need people to follow instructions like robots or do routine calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate obstacles, we'll have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his innovative work 'combinatorial play.' He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam and catching it, then thinking about the consequences. We can't teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling focused on imposed questions with one right answer. More important than creativity is getting along with others, caring for them, and cooperating. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit anytime. If you can't quit, it's not play. Players know they must keep others happy to continue the game. This makes play the most democratic activity. School has become more demanding: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and pressure for high grades has grown. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults present have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now feel they must intervene rather than let children solve their own problems. These changes have been gradual but significant, caused by social factors like parents' fears, expert warnings about dangers, declining neighborhood cohesion, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children don't need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must reverse the negative trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They need to follow their natural drives to play and explore to grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Platforms like Twitter and LinkedIn allow direct contact with potential employers, similar to standing outside an office with a "hire me" sign. However, this access also increases the risk of mistakes. For example, a young jobseeker in the US reached out to a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn, hoping to use her contacts to get a job. The executive, offended by this request from a stranger, not only rejected him but also sent a harsh, sarcastic reply that went viral. Many who saw the note online were shocked, and the executive might regret her tone, though not the message. This incident highlights the importance of using social media carefully in a professional context. Social media can be risky for job seekers who misuse it, and many are making mistakes. 

Ironically, social media has been central to the social lives of twentysomethings for years. For my generation, it was a way to escape from parents and teachers, a place to impress and experiment. It was often based on fantasy, where you could chat with someone online and ignore them in person. You could change your image overnight with the right Facebook posts. But using social media for professional networking is different, and our familiarity with platforms like Facebook might be a disadvantage. We learned to be bold and confident online, which might explain why some still think this works professionally. Just because your Facebook posts were popular doesn't mean LinkedIn will help you impress employers. We need to understand that our teenage social media habits don't apply in the professional world, and we must meet employers' expectations to succeed.

Employers often complain that young job seekers on professional sites are too informal and seem arrogant, reinforcing the stereotype of an "entitled generation." In reality, many young people are desperate for jobs, which is why they turn to social media. This perceived arrogance can harm their job prospects, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees. So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly introduce yourself and explain what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach increases your chances of a positive response. Avoid sending generic emails and keep your tone humble to prevent a negative reaction. Remember, social media can help you make valuable connections, but it requires careful use to avoid closing doors.

Predicting the future of newspapers is very difficult. If someone claims they can do it accurately, they might not be truthful. Looking at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in trouble. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to half. In the USA, the Pew Research Centre found that only 26% of people now get their news from newspapers, compared to 45% in 2001. Many people predict that printed newspapers will disappear in about 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. In 1835, a New York journalist wrongly predicted that books and theatre would become obsolete, but they have survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived even with TV, and cinema has stayed popular despite videos and DVDs. Vinyl records have even made a comeback, with a 745% increase in online sales since 2008.

Newspapers were once new media too, but it took centuries for them to become the main source of news. This happened in the mid-19th century with the steam press, railway, and telegraph. It was also because people started to believe that everything is always changing and they needed regular updates, a concept that was unfamiliar in medieval times. Back then, people only noticed the changing seasons and unexpected disasters like famine or disease. Life was seen as cyclical, with recurring truths, as writer Alain de Botton explains.

Journalism as a full-time job only really started in the 19th century. Even then, there was no clear reason why people needed news regularly. The regular publication of newspapers can be limiting. Online news allows readers to check updates based on their interests and the importance of events. Advanced search engines and algorithms let us customize news to our preferences. Online news can provide minute-by-minute updates and correct errors quickly. There are no space limits, so stories can be detailed, and full documents can be accessed. This is very different from traditional newspapers.

However, many online news providers focus on being the first to report news, getting reader comments, and creating excitement, which can lead to confusion. In medieval times, news was shared in busy places like markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors and misunderstandings. In some ways, we are returning to that kind of world. Newspapers have not always been great at explaining how the world works. They might face extinction, or they might find a way to help us understand our complex world, as the internet adds to our feeling of living in a chaotic universe, as de Botton suggests.

If humans were naturally comfortable under the moon and stars, we would enjoy the darkness, seeing the midnight world as clearly as many nocturnal animals do. However, we are creatures of the day, with eyes suited for sunlight. This is a fundamental part of our genetics, even if we don't often think of ourselves as daytime beings, just as we don't constantly consider ourselves primates or mammals. This explains why we've altered the night by filling it with artificial light. This control over our environment is similar to building a dam on a river. While it has benefits, it also brings problems, known as light pollution, which scientists are just beginning to study. Light pollution mainly comes from poor lighting design, where artificial light spreads outward and upward into the sky instead of being directed downward where it's needed. This poorly designed lighting brightens the night, disrupting the natural light levels and rhythms that many life forms, including humans, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light enters the natural world, it affects life processes like migration, reproduction, and feeding. For most of human history, the idea of 'light pollution' would have been meaningless. Imagine approaching London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the world's largest city. Nearly a million people lived there, relying on candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and public gaslights wouldn't appear for another seven years. From a distance, you would have smelled London before seeing its faint glow. We've illuminated the night as if it were empty, but that's far from true. Among mammals alone, many species are nocturnal. Light is a strong biological force, attracting many species. It's so powerful that scientists describe songbirds and seabirds as being 'captured' by searchlights on land or gas flares on marine oil platforms, circling until they fall. Birds migrating at night often crash into brightly lit tall buildings, with young birds on their first journey being most affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd hours due to artificial light. It was once thought that light pollution only troubled astronomers, who need a clear night sky for their work. Unlike astronomers, most of us don't need an unobstructed view of the night sky, but like most creatures, we do need darkness. Ignoring the need for darkness is pointless. It's as crucial for our biological health as light is; disrupting our internal clock can lead to various health issues. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping in our lives mirrors the Earth's cycle of light and dark. These rhythms are so essential to us that disturbing them is like changing our center of gravity. Ultimately, humans are as affected by light pollution as frogs near a brightly lit highway. Living in our own artificial glare, we've disconnected from our evolutionary and cultural heritage—the light of the stars and the natural rhythms of day and night. Light pollution makes us lose sight of our true place in the universe, forgetting our scale, which is best understood against the vastness of a deep night with the Milky Way arching overhead.

The founder of a large international company recently announced that his company will stop tracking how much paid holiday time employees take. This decision was inspired by an internet company that has a similar policy. The founder got the idea from an email from his daughter, which seemed like it was written by someone from his media team. While the announcement might seem like an attempt to make the company appear more caring, we should consider if the idea is practical.

The internet company and the multinational corporation are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational has 50,000 employees and many different services, like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want, as long as it doesn't harm the business" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other's workloads. In a large company, it's harder to be sure that taking time off won't affect the business.

The founder said employees can take as much leave as they want if they are sure their work is up to date and their absence won't harm the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? Even if you prepare before a holiday, work will pile up while you're away. This is just how taking leave works. Employees might end up not taking any leave or feeling guilty if they do. This guilt can lead to stress and lower productivity over time.

There could also be pressure from colleagues about who takes time off and for how long. In the corporate world, there's already a culture of working late, and this could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave, where employees compete for promotions. Without the security of legally guaranteed leave, people might feel they can't take the time off they need without seeming lazy.

Modern technology blurs the line between work and free time, as we can receive work messages anywhere. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees questioned how the new way of working fit with the old time-off policy. If the company can't track work hours accurately, why should it apply an outdated standard to time off? However, without set working hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might feel they are always being watched, leading them to self-monitor in a harmful way.

Employment laws exist to ensure workers get a minimum amount of paid leave because rest is important for health. The benefits of the unlimited leave policy, like increased morale and productivity, can happen without affecting worker well-being. Therefore, I doubt that allowing employees to take as much holiday as they want is the real goal or likely result of this policy.

Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in a field evaluate a scientific research paper before it is published. It is seen as a way to ensure the quality of research by preventing flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. This process can delay publication by up to a year, raising the question of whether this delay is worth it to ensure trust in scientific literature. The answer is both yes and no, as this issue highlights the changing nature of scientific publishing.

While I still believe in some form of review before formal publication, the landscape is shifting. Preprints, which are drafts of papers shared online without peer review, are becoming more common. They allow for the quick sharing of new research so it can be read, critiqued, and built upon. However, publishing in journals has become more about gaining recognition and advancing careers, which can lead to authors cutting corners and reviewers focusing more on whether a paper is suitable for a prestigious journal rather than its scientific quality.

These issues are well-known, but few are willing to change the current system. Preprints might offer a solution because they don't require a drastic change from the norm. Despite being around for twenty years, preprints haven't been widely adopted due to scientists' conservative nature and the misconception that journals won't accept papers already posted as preprints. There's also a fear that publishing without peer review could lead to an increase in poor-quality science, though this hasn't happened yet.

Preprints are open to critique and discussion by a global community, which can be beneficial. For example, Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, found that posting a preprint allowed for open discussion and critique, which isn't always possible with traditional journals. Preprints also allow for the sharing of negative results, an important part of science often overlooked by journals focused on new discoveries. Additionally, papers on preprint archives are read and cited more, showing the effectiveness of this method of sharing research.

By embracing the internet's culture of openness and collaboration, preprints can help shift the focus back to the quality of the work itself, rather than where it is published.

When I ask my literature students to define a poem, they often say it's like 'a painting in words.' These answers usually don't satisfy either of us. So, one day, I asked them to pick an object and write two paragraphs: one describing it like a scientist, and another from the object's perspective, titled 'Poem.' One student wrote: 

Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I'm a device that helps people breathe. I'm only used in emergencies and even then, only for a short time. Most people will never need me. 

The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise led to laughter and meaningful discussion. 

When I was in school, poetry often seemed confusing to me. I thought of each poem as a complicated puzzle that blocked true understanding and emotion. After school, many people find poetry less engaging. Sometimes, you come across a poem, and it stands out because it's not like regular prose. It almost challenges you to read it, and often, you feel let down by its simplicity or because it’s hard to understand at first. Still, you feel good for trying. 

What do we expect from poems? Aren't they supposed to hold deep emotions, beautiful images, gentle thoughts, or sharp humor? The answer might seem to be yes. But if we want to cry, we watch movies; for information or sharp critique, we read online articles. Novels offer us worlds to escape to, paintings give us visual pleasure, and music – well, nothing beats the mix of lyrics, instruments, and melody. 

However, one thing a poem can offer is ambiguity. Everyday life is full of it, unlike straightforward reading. But these thoughts still don't explain what a poem truly is. If you search online for 'poem,' it redirects to 'poetry': 'a form of literary art using the aesthetic and rhythmic qualities of language.' This is academic language, but it hides the word's origins. 'Poem' comes from the Greek 'poí?ma,' meaning 'a thing made,' and a poet is 'a maker of things.' So, if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? 

Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or to machines – precise and human-made – depending on their perspective. But these comparisons don't hold up under scrutiny. The value in trying to define a poem through comparison is not in the comparison itself but in the discussion it sparks. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about machines or wild animals. It helps the mind explore new ways of thinking and see ordinary things differently. 

Thinking of a poem as a mental object isn't hard, especially when we consider how song lyrics can stick in our minds. The mix of words and melody has a strong effect, like schoolyard rhymes such as 'Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me.' But aren't words sometimes like sticks and stones? 

Consider a poem on a newspaper or magazine page, staring at you: A poem can impact you like nothing else, even though, in terms of ink on paper, it does nothing more than the prose around it. What about all that empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or ad? A poem is created through writing and rewriting, just like an article, story, or novel, but it never really becomes a commodity. Publishing houses send out press releases and review copies of poetry collections, but few expect them to cover printing costs. A poem presents itself not as a market product, but as something for its own sake. Because of its special status – set apart in a magazine or book – a poem can still surprise us, even if only for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after getting married. Back then, £70 was a lot of money, and it might have been wiser to spend it on something practical for the house. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, every brooch and coin I've found has brought me joy because it connects me to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had some free time and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot known for old farming machinery. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I almost ignored it but couldn't resist checking. I dug half a meter down and was lying in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden object. I tried not to get too excited, thinking it might be brass like before. But as I cleared the dirt, it turned out to be a beautifully patterned loop. I stopped and stared, realizing it looked like the Great Torc in the British Museum, a famous piece from Iron Age Britain over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a twisted gold and silver necklace with gold rings at each end, just like what I found.

I took it to the car and couldn't stop looking at it on the drive home. I washed it in the kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in ages. I called Marion, saying, "I've got something for you." She came in, stopped, and asked, "What is it?" I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on, fearing it might get damaged. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe, but anxiety kept me awake. Eventually, I hid it under a floorboard in my office.

The law requires reporting such finds within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc before handing it over, even taking it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned, stopped mid-sentence, and stared. The torc was authenticated and sold to my local council. It's now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 proceeds were split between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just a lucky find; it's something I've preserved for the nation. People ask if I'll stop detecting now that I've found something so amazing. But those brooches and coins are still fascinating. Like a fisherman who catches a big fish, I won't stop while there's a chance of finding something even bigger.

Sleeping is one of my favorite parts of traveling, but I don't often talk about it because I feel a bit guilty. When friends describe their carefully planned trips, filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. I wonder what they would think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during Caribbean rainstorms and lazy mornings in Italian sheets. Better sleep is a happy bonus of traveling. When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—over 12 hours most days. Even with noisy birds nearby, it didn't bother me. Away from home, in a new environment, I could sleep deeply and dream more vividly than I thought possible. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I don't think just relaxing explains why travel sleep feels so different. I believe sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we encounter new sights, sounds, and smells. We absorb different cultures, music, and landscapes. Sleep helps us process all this new information. That's why sleep feels more intense when traveling. Sleep also changes with each place. People worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local customs affects me more than time zones. In Trinidad, for example, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to adjust to this new sleep pattern. Once I do, I feel like I've truly arrived. I remember an afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, where I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, we all relaxed on hammocks and sofas. I finally understood the Latin American tradition of the siesta. I didn't just sleep; I experienced a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is memorable. Away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my dreams. If 'slow travel'—fully enjoying each experience rather than rushing—is what defines the modern traveler, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed and tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one suits you best," she said diplomatically to her customer. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking a bit like a bulldog. "But it's so boring," she said. "Everyone will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little one will make me stand out." She patted the red and black mini top hat on her head. "Yes," she decided, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change her mind, so she smiled and agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. She thought of her own daughter, Jen, whose thirtieth birthday was today. They were having a family gathering, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious about the friend Jen was bringing, someone they knew nothing about. Her husband Jeff had been quick to comment when Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie. "Tattie," Jeff said when Mia told him, "What kind of name is that?" "It's short for Tatiana," Mia replied. "I think it’s nice." "Sounds pretentious," Jeff retorted. He disliked anything showy and didn't believe in being overly polite, which he called Mia’s reluctance to speak her mind. He wouldn’t have hesitated to tell the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat. He might have even said a trash can lid would suit her better. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite for your own good." An hour later, Mia closed the shop and entered Medlar House through the back door; her commute was just forty seconds. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia decided to convert the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think there's a demand for hats?" he asked. Mia knew from friends who struggled to find the perfect hat for special occasions that there was definitely a demand. She was right. From the start, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats was a success. Women came from far away to her showroom in Little Pelham, where she offered a relaxed environment to try on as many hats as needed. With changing rooms available, she encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure everything matched. Recently, she expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry.

It's a long journey from London to Atlanta, and Lawrence Okoye is reflecting on his incredible sports career. He is confident, yet even he is a bit surprised by how far he has come—from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly joining a major American football team. Despite never having played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be selected by a top USA team. In Atlanta, he is still learning the details of his new position. The idea that a 21-year-old from London, who is new to the sport, could be chosen for one of the biggest teams in American sports seems unbelievable. But Lawrence is used to overcoming doubts. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but delayed it to focus on discus, after previously playing rugby. Within 20 months, he became the world's fourth-best discus thrower. Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training, aiming for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in a potential NFL contract, he confirms, "American football was in the back of my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. I had thought about it in school, but it seemed crazy then." Soon after arriving in America, he learned about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, he thought he might be good enough to try out. "Pretty much," he says. "I went online and applied." Was he nervous about competing with experienced American football players? "No," he says. "I don't get nervous about many things." He doesn't talk much, but his confidence is clear. His performance in various tests and drills made him stand out as the most impressive player. "I was very pleased to hear that," he admits, showing a rare hint of pride. However, he is also cautious. Without any basic experience, how can he make it into an NFL team? "Coaches say I have all the necessary attributes. It's just about how hard I work," he explains. Is he relaxed while waiting to hear if he's been selected? "I am. There's no pressure on me. Many people say I'll definitely be selected, but I'm not too worried." This calm attitude might come from his disappointing Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved past this and is proud that he made it to the final with an impressive last throw. "That was an amazing day," he recalls. "The final didn't go as I wanted, but that's part of sports. It's something I can return to." After his Olympic setback, some thought the experience had affected him. Lawrence doesn't comment on this. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, so the financial benefits are clear. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his great physical abilities, wouldn't it be better to focus on one sport? "I understand why someone would say that," he replies. "I'm trying to achieve something I've dreamed about since I was a schoolkid. If it doesn't work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I've made has been well thought out."

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daylight. Looking out the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, even though it was mid-September, it hadn't started snowing in Siberia yet. There was no sign of human life, just an endless view of mountains, streams, and forests. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow, traveling to remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I managed to explain that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he reasoned, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it anymore. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked unconvinced and said "Holodna" (cold), pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, though I didn't mention that my trip was self-funded and I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at discounted prices. I wasn't sure they would be up to the task, especially my large postman's over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students slumped in their seats, some taking notes without energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking hard about a particular dilemma. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me slouched Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to decipher my scrawl, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still far from having full control of my classes, the job ticked many important boxes for me. It was frequently challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling, and, of course, there were long holidays to chase adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug in a big way after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more relaxing than teaching: to cycle around the world. Ever since that first ride we took together, Al had been setting himself greater and greater challenges. This round-the-world-by-bike trip was certainly his greatest so far. At times, he thought the ride or the road would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding that he could handle each new challenge even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the skeptics who said he couldn't do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through pylons that are 15 to 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it's like to participate. An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first confirmed I was healthy, and the second required me to empty my pockets because small objects can become dangerous during the flight. I learned I needed to stay oriented by keeping an eye on the horizon. The pilot would tell me where to look. I was also asked to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down. 

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything. As we taxied down the runway, I tried not to touch the steering pedals with my feet or the switches with my hands. My mind was made up: I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying. To avoid passing out, you must stay calm and focused. You need to tense up and relax at the right times. Panicking is not a good idea. This was not comforting as we started accelerating down the runway. Dario, the pilot, and I reached the end of the runway in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off, and two seconds later, we made a sharp right turn. It was a sudden, intense move, and I felt the air squeeze out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed up, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned sharply left and dived, leaving my stomach at 2,000 meters and my lungs pressed against the roof of the plane. Seconds later, we were 10 meters off the ground, heading for the small space between two pylons. They passed at 400 km per hour, but my brief excitement was interrupted by a sharp right turn. We hadn't even started the acrobatics yet.
