For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane. My hand shook so much that the plane shook too—it’s that responsive. Then Dario said something. I asked him to repeat it, but instead, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I replied. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane in a full circle in the air. I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was a bit much. At the top of the loop, flying upside down, I heard a small voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw some fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what the pilots experience during a race. To prove the point, Dario got out some sandwiches as soon as we landed and started eating happily. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I dreamed of doing loops over and over again.

Doug Allan is a wildlife cameraman who films animals in cold places. If you've ever seen amazing footage of polar bears in a documentary, it was likely filmed by him. He prefers temperatures around -18C. Allan started as a marine biologist and commercial diver, which taught him how to survive in cold environments. His career took off when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where he was working, to film a wildlife documentary. He helped them find locations and realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for him because it combined travel, adventure, and underwater filming. Now, he is a leading cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series.

Allan says he started at a good time because few people had been to Antarctica then. There were experts for different animals, like coral or elephants, but he became known for filming in cold places. Back then, camera technology was basic. It’s easier to film now with digital technology because you can shoot a lot and review it immediately. In the past, film was expensive, so you had to plan your shots carefully. 

Allan's strength is his experience in cold conditions. He feels comfortable on sea ice, like crossing a street. He admits to getting cold toes but says the poles are healthy places without leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes. Wildlife filming has its successes and failures. Once, he went to the Orkneys to film kittiwakes but couldn’t identify them.

Recently, Allan filmed in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, known for polar bears and difficult conditions. It’s usually -32C in April, with strong winds and deep snow. After 23 days of watching polar bear dens, he had only seen one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, he felt in tune with the bears. He describes waiting by a hole and finally seeing a bear emerge, followed by her cubs. It was a special moment, like having front-row seats to a show.

Allan now wants to make a film about climate change in the Arctic, focusing on the people who live there and experience its effects. He believes he could create an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting supplies along the way. This meant he had to swim through freezing waters and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, preparing for an even more challenging expedition. Explorers are confident and driven, and Pen is no exception. This time, however, the stakes are higher. Pen and two colleagues will embark on a three-month, 1,000-kilometer journey to the North Pole to measure the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and the results will be crucial for scientists. This will provide the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the polar ice. Pen was trained for this kind of work. As a child, he was cared for by his father's old nanny, who had worked for the famous explorer Scott of the Antarctic. She toughened him up by sending him out into blizzards with minimal clothing. His father also passed on a love for icy adventures, and Pen showed remarkable physical endurance. Pen is married to Mary, a horsewoman who says he has a "spine of steel" and shares his love for the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and worries more about him when he's at home, saying, "He's in more danger driving along the A303 because in his head, he's somewhere in the Arctic." For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horseback compete against runners. Mary and her horse finished an hour ahead of Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. "It's much harder to be away from them this time," he admits. "They were one and five when I last went, and I made a mistake in how I said goodbye. I told my son, 'You're the man of the house now, look after your mum and sister.' He took it seriously, but it was too much pressure. It was well-intentioned but unfair." For similar reasons, he plans to have little contact with them while in the Arctic. "If you call them, you remind them how far away you are." He is spending his last days before departure preparing his gear meticulously. "On the ice, you can't fix things or do anything that's not straightforward," he says. Joining him will be Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support crew of six flying in supplies. Being part of a team is more stressful for someone like Pen, and he has other concerns too. "I'm turning 47 on Thursday. I've done less training than I'd like." Why? "Organizational tasks always seem more urgent. So I'm almost afraid of what I'll ask of myself." Pen believes his mission reconnects exploration with the quest for knowledge that inspired past explorers. "Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal," he admits, "and not very useful beyond the polar adventuring community. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we're engaging as many people as possible in what's happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it," he says. "Our skills, which seemed odd and unnecessary, are now very relevant. Suddenly, we're useful to society again."

I took a year off and wondered what to do next. Being an Olympian is amazing, and I had opportunities to write, work on TV, and speak at schools and businesses. Despite these activities, I missed having a competitive challenge. I wanted to stay fit in case I decided to compete in the Olympics again, so I started running marathons and doing triathlons. But there was still Ben Fogle's invitation in my mind: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I love rowing and missed the feeling of the boat gliding through water, but I wasn't ready for intense training every day. I talked to some rowing friends about the race, but none were interested. I knew if I joined, I would want to win, and I wasn't sure if Ben was the best partner for that. However, the idea of being an underdog with no pressure was appealing. Ben was already planning to do the race and had managed to gather the entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the costs, which were high—£70,000 for the boat and equipment alone. We thought we had a good chance, but it would require effort to secure everything. Besides the race expenses, I also had to consider the loss of income from being away. Speaking at business conferences is a lucrative way for retired athletes to earn money, and while it's flattering, I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Joining the race meant I could talk about something current: rowing across the Atlantic. Planning this adventure taught me to appreciate the simpler life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but straightforward, with set training programs and support from doctors and dieticians. I worried about how people would perceive me racing with a TV presenter, fearing it might seem like I just wanted TV exposure. But during our preparations, those concerns faded. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about mental strength than just rowing skills. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island, but he couldn't row well. I was surprised by his lack of natural rowing ability, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have expected his skill level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of Arctic landscapes, cold and empty, maybe as a reaction to the noise and crowds of London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, deep in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they take tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, lasting from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to over 100. Recently, they took over a second property, the 'wilderness farm', which they described as a beautiful but basic place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They said I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.' I started packing right away.

November 6, London On my flight, I stare at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies; I am supposed to memorize their names before I arrive, but I feel distracted and panicky. I put the page down and look out the window instead. It is said that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, like a wave of blooming flowers and leaves. But I think I am seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and the rivers freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests of thin conifers, heavy with snow, stopping occasionally to let reindeer move out of the way. I arrive at the farm after dark and am barely through the door when I’m given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking, which becomes a wall of noise by the time I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth, harnessing the huskies to sleds. The dogs are almost hysterical with excitement, eager to start. I can barely hear to introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much anyway. I stand on the sidelines and rub the forehead of one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command rings out, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a head torch for light.

November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but not before a discouraging questioning about what I bring to the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I’m stumped. I don’t know. Am I? Further questions reveal that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become difficult in sub-zero conditions. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is spinning with instructions, and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds – and from being dragged around by overenthusiastic huskies. But I am triumphant. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, when Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the press gathered to understand her incredible run. Her time was so fast that it would qualify her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were curious about a natural treatment she used, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended. Radcliffe used it to heal after a training accident where she ran into a bike. Radcliffe says the achievement didn't really sink in at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day. Her team had a motto: no limits.

During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Her physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, was also there. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried she might not keep up the pace and could drop out. Hartmann was angry at this, though he admitted that anyone who didn't know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so fast. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had run 41 kilometers at a very fast speed but still managed to sprint the final distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run quicker than that." The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would come close to that time soon, but Radcliffe thought, "I'm going to come back and do it next year." Unfortunately, that didn't happen.

After the race, people wondered how an athlete with such an awkward running style could beat the graceful East African runners. Hartmann had spent weeks with Radcliffe, giving her daily sessions to help with the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle that level of pain like her. She would push me to go so deep into her muscles that I had to ice my thumbs afterward." Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to her training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for pleasantries; she was ready for a two-hour session. Radcliffe would push him to give everything he had, which made her so good. During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became resentful.

Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? "Not really. I trained really hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought it might happen with Mary Keitany (a two-time London marathon winner). Maybe it's because people are racing each other more than racing themselves." What does she mean? "That mental way of never easing up, even when you've won the race, probably pushed me to it because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always: 'keep pushing as hard as you can.'" Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run as fast again. However, she left a lasting legacy, inspiring many women to take up long-distance running.

When my first cookery show, "In Search of Perfection," was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. At the time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' happening in Britain. I believed our series was a fresh and innovative addition to this movement. However, I was concerned whether people would appreciate a cooking approach that included not just techniques but also history, nostalgia, and science. I watched the first episode with a mix of excitement and anxiety. Fortunately, I had nothing to worry about. The show's success led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether exploring the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called "Perfection," each with its own TV show. These journeys were often physical, involving travel with passports and suitcases. "In Search of Total Perfection" is the latest in the series, where you travel the world to meet extraordinary artisans, like a man dedicated to making the best-tasting golden pasta. These people have spent years pursuing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was challenging, and I knew some people would be disappointed if their favorites were left out. I imagined people asking, "Where's steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?" However, after a long meeting, the TV team and I created a list that had something for everyone. This confirmed my belief that everyone has their own idea of perfection, influenced by emotions, memories, and surroundings. Despite the book's title, I never claimed the recipes were 'definitive.' But I thought that by using my technical skills and scientific knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines 'perfection' as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. Trying ideas and refining them until they become unique. The TV series allowed me to explore foods, people, and places I hadn't encountered before, which was as exciting as exploring memory and nostalgia in food. I began my career in this way, searching for the best ingredients took me around the world. Some adventures included visiting a canning factory that processed the wrong type of tomato and a dairy farm with low standards where we had to stop filming. Perfecting each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow to make ice cream with dry ice, cooking chicken breasts in a hospital scanner, and nearly setting my house on fire trying to heat the oven for a Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a few hours away from Marrakech when the van suddenly made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out to check the engine, looking like he knew what he was doing. But after a while, he admitted, "Actually, I have no idea what I'm doing," and he and Mum started laughing. Bea was worried and said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was vast, with just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea because it was usually best to be on her side. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. John went off to find someone who could help with the van, and Mum lay on the grass. "Tell us a story," she said. Bea lay down next to her, and I started telling them about how I heard two birds talking the day before we left London. I told them about the things the birds discussed, like breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and a fight over a worm. Bea said, "That's silly, no one understands bird language." I insisted I did, but my voice wasn't convincing. "Liar," she said, and I felt embarrassed. I wasn't sure anymore if I had really understood the birds. I looked to Mum for support, but she had fallen asleep. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped push the van to a hotel. Bea didn't want to get out, but the boys didn't mind and waved at her. We followed John into a café near where the van was parked. "It's a hotel," John whispered, "It might be expensive." Mum said we'd just have tea, and we sat on the terrace. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum said, "It's like syrup." We stayed there all day while John tried to fix the van. "It's a miracle it got us this far," he said as it got dark. Mum made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on solid ground. John said he'd have to get us towed into Marrakech. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed with John driving it. Bea didn't want to move at first, so John carried her into the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I wondered how we'd get home since the van needed towing. I thought maybe we could take a boat straight to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. Unlike Lucy, they weren't competing. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city, but Lucy didn't catch her name clearly over the noise. It was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the music they were playing, their recent travels, and their future plans. 

Lucy mentioned she might be going to the Tanglewood festival that summer, which sounded impressive. However, she didn't really want to go. She often felt this way about the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, causing her to miss so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. Lucy hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she was chosen. Her dad celebrated by buying her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant, and her little brother Gus dreamed of attending the festival himself one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. 

The thing was, Lucy hadn't applied to the festival herself. Her mother had filled out the application and sent in a CD. Her mom said she didn't want Lucy to be disappointed if she didn't get in. Lucy thought it was more about not giving her the chance to say no. At that time, Lucy believed that causing trouble was the worst thing to do, so she didn't even think about trying to back out.

The guy from Tokyo leaned forward, surprised. "Tanglewood?" he asked. "Yeah," Lucy replied. "How old are you?" he asked. "Fifteen," she said. He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, "Wow." Lucy hadn't meant to brag. It was hard to know when sharing her achievements was just fitting in or showing off. "It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying..." she explained. Liesel/Louisa excused herself, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, "Have you ever been to Japan?" He had long, shaggy hair, like many male musicians, to show they were rebels. "Once, when I was about eight," Lucy replied. He was about to say something when Lucy's grandfather appeared. "Lucy, let me introduce you to someone," he said, taking her arm and pulling her away. "And don't get too friendly with the competition." "They're not the competition," Lucy said. "Everyone is the competition," her grandfather replied.

He took her around the room, introducing her to people he thought were important. Lucy smiled and nodded, only half-listening. In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather said, "You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are." Lucy liked that part—being somebody. Even if it made some people jealous or think she was too young for the attention she got. Being a concert pianist didn't earn her any special respect from the kids she used to go to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro perfectly. But in places like this, she knew she mattered.

Dad said, "Spending too much time online isn't good for you. You need to experience the real world." It's hard to argue with him, so I looked into what experts say about this topic, and it's quite interesting. Research generally shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity and belonging, and are developing important technical skills needed for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is now a key part of growing up. Teenagers don't just use media occasionally like adults do; they live in it. It's not about whether it's good or bad, but how you use it that matters.

Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, compares social networking to what our parents did at our age. He says it's like a modern version of hanging out at a youth club, where parents used to share jokes and gossip. It helps teenagers develop their identity away from their parents and learn to interact with peers. Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson explains that adolescence is a time of self-discovery, and social networking can help with that. It allows teenagers to share their interests and learn about different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are less self-centered than those who don't use social media. He also mentions that social media can be helpful for shy people, as online communication can be less intimidating than face-to-face interactions.

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can be beneficial for quiet individuals with specific interests, as they allow them to connect with others who share those interests. For example, if only a few people at your school like a certain type of music, you might feel isolated. But finding a group online with similar interests can make you feel more connected and popular in a different way.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says that young people who find new interests online and create their own content are truly using the potential of social networks. She believes social networking is becoming a creative force, with teenagers making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are also enhancing creativity, allowing photographers to connect, learn, and share their work. This can improve employability and be beneficial in the workplace, as businesses use social media to sell products and increase brand awareness. If you have many friends on social networks, they can become potential customers for your products. Matthews agrees that teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit in their future careers. He highlights that collaboration, a key feature of many sites, is an essential 21st-century skill and important for being employable in the digital age.

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, a long road trip through nine western US states and a Canadian province might not be the first thing that comes to mind. However, my parents had a different idea for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to plan what many teenagers would consider a nightmare: a big family bonding trip. "Not enough people do this anymore," my parents kept saying before the trip, while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There's probably a reason for that!"

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough room left for us, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." Leaving our spacious home for more "cozy" accommodations over the next five thousand miles, I wasn't the only one wondering what we were getting into.

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under some of the darkest, star-filled skies in the country, but only after nearly being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way!

The next day, we were up at dawn and on the move again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains, and the days started to blend together, but each adventure was unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town gave us a hint of what was to come later in our journey. As we climbed to our next destination, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best left to Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of ancient and modern. Dodging construction traffic became routine. We laughed as we posed by the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument.

We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common, and our own close encounter with a bear and a worried park ranger gave us unforgettable memories. As we continued, life back home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with its creaky floors and no internet or cell phone service, couldn't dampen our spirits. In exchange, I got to see the most amazing views I've ever seen.

After watching a rainstorm from our cozy hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to an exotic foreign land to find something remarkable. It was bittersweet to be home again, but at least I hadn't fought with my brother during our hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos of our crazy journey to look through and remember. For me, the most memorable parts were the unplanned and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost, a sixteen-year-old, was moving to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Her family was splitting up for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, was joining him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school and living under the care of the college Head. She was happy to have the best room at the college, complete with a kitchen, study area, and free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still be keeping an eye on Amy.

Rose was going to her grandmother's house. She only had vague holiday memories of Daisy and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not thrilled, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and was excited to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn't fully understand why her parents had issues with Daisy, but there had been a disagreement in the past, leading to holidays spent elsewhere. Rose's last goodbye to Daisy was when she was ten, but her memories were happy.

Dahlia mentioned that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and good at bringing people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon. This made Rose smile. Daisy was not a typical frail grandmother; she seemed to attend more social events than the Queen of England. Before moving, Dahlia and Rose had a talk. Rose was mature and knew about healthy living. She wanted independence, like playing loud music, inviting friends over, or going out without always asking for permission. She didn't want to be nagged about homework or staying out late, and she didn't want to be dragged around by her grandmother. Daisy understood.

Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen phone with a video camera for emergencies. Rose was thrilled. They agreed it was about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be overbearing. If either went too far, they would talk about it. Rose was never a wild child, and her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. She knew this was the last time, as she would start her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new chapter in her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book was a big achievement because it seemed challenging, and she wasn't aware of what other teenagers were doing, like participating in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to give it a try. The novel she started then is now about to be published. She recently told her former teacher, who was surprised, as the teacher had expected Charlotte to write a book at 30 or 40. Charlotte couldn't understand why she should wait to pursue something she might be good at.

On a winter afternoon at her publisher's office, I was surprised to see a teenager, even though I knew I was interviewing a 15-year-old about her book. The book is impressive: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing, except the heroine's age, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs support, but she doesn't. Charlotte is independent, spirited, intelligent, and steady, which keeps her from being overconfident.

Charlotte recognizes the limits of her youth. When asked about the complex moral issues in her book, she says she wanted to ask big questions, not answer them. She laughs, saying she doesn't have many life lessons to share. She doesn't think her age limits her understanding of the world, but she doesn't consider herself particularly wise either. She was interested in exploring the theme of taking responsibility.

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are portrayed in fiction aimed at them. She believes there are three types: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager unaware of the world, and the socially awkward teenager. She found these stereotypes frustrating. She wonders why there aren't more stories about teenagers who are fine as they are. She feels that some writers unintentionally suggest teenagers can't know themselves because they lack experience, which can undermine their confidence.

Charlotte has always enjoyed reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. Their books explore deep psychological and life themes, which made her question if she needed to do the same to write a good book. However, she appreciates a book called "How Not to Write a Novel," which advises that if readers can predict the story, the suspense is lost.

Some might think Charlotte's parents, both journalists, helped her get published. Her father's connection in publishing did get her book read initially. She acknowledges her luck, as getting a first novel read is difficult, regardless of the author's age. Charlotte concludes that every writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, success depends on talent, so she doesn't take her success for granted.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show he knew what he was doing, went first. He skied down the slope towards the jump, hit the ramp fast, and flew into the air with his arms flailing. Even we could tell something was wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle stuff. On past skiing holidays, I enjoyed practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how, and I feared being laughed at by the skateboarders with their baggy trousers and special language. Then my parents decided on a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a huge indoor facility near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students would leap, try new tricks, and land in foam pits – not a realistic introduction to the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan assured us. ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat section behind the jump before the slope steepens again. Land in the zone, and you keep moving forward, minimizing impact. Land on the flat, and you stop suddenly, which is painful. Hence the need for speed. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my brain and race towards the jump. My legs would almost go into reverse as I neared the launch point, so I came down onto the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing was addictive. Some drills copied ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body is doing as you spin in space. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I was only aware of the moment before take-off, then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a moment I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that didn’t last. On the final run of the day, I kept my speed as I approached the jump, became airborne, and landed in the zone. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you're on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and your nails dig into the harness. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs upwards. There's a pause, then a sharp drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You grit your teeth as you speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you let out a scream from deep inside. But you chose this: like millions of others each year, you paid to enter the theme park.

It's interesting that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, are such a big industry. To create the excitement and escape that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it's actually a big challenge. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe, and they need to add new features to keep people coming back.

Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers are limited to the tracks made by specialist manufacturers.

I spoke to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer,' said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, from the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that it's about quickly switching between different forces so people feel thrilled but safe. It's a fine line between excitement and discomfort.

To create an amazing ride, teams must build a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with new features like the tallest ride or the most twists. However, Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trial-and-error are key. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that being a thrill-seeker helps designers understand what passengers want and test rides before they open to the public.

I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, will change rollercoaster design. Walker said not to expect too much. Virtual reality can add a layer of excitement, like painting an old rollercoaster, but the physical ride experience will remain the main attraction for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating pieces for many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances occasionally. I'm curious why she fits both activities into her busy schedule. She explains, "Dancing again reminds me of what it's like to be in the studio, taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it's like to rehearse all day." As a choreographer, she enjoys teaching and working with young students. "New dancers are often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want success but don't fully know their strengths and weaknesses yet. This incomplete understanding makes them open to even harsh criticism. They might challenge me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback."

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her work. "There might be music I'm not fond of, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don't respond well to a certain composer's music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can't just choose a new piece. Ideally, I'd like to be more experimental and switch to different pieces, which would help lift the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I'm always working on big productions where the musical score is already set by the composer and can't be changed."

Miranda doesn't like to stick to one institution. "I think it's important to keep meeting new people. But I have to remember that the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So I need to adapt my work each time I go somewhere new, rather than doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways."

We talk about a recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. "There have been glamorous documentaries before that were misleading," says Miranda. "This one tries to show viewers what life inside a dance company is really like. There was a scene where a young dancer gets endless corrections, and I recognized that. She knows she's not getting it right but can't make her body do what's needed. It's painful to watch but not staged for the cameras. The public underestimates the work and dedication involved in ballet."

I'm curious about what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. "It's when everything the company has invested in – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – all come together. Perfection might be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can make up for a few wrong artistic choices. I've been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props is distracting. That's disappointing."

Miranda has done a wide range of work, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? "People want to label you, and I don't understand that. There's also a trend to develop expertise in a narrow area. I don't follow that, though I might one day be happy to be known for one thing. For now, I want to broaden my horizons."

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on television. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there's so much to experience outside? That conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of an old sofa, which became the main feature of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to secure myself. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night, even spending one night on the beach. Several friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to continue. I've been on many walking trips in recent years, but this was completely different. It was the longest distance I've ever walked, and it was on main roads, so I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I got used to telling people, "No, I'm not doing it for charity, and I'm not training for a marathon." When someone at work asks about my weekend, I'd rather explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was thrilled. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be a good fit for me. At the Greek port, the man seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. Although he still seemed puzzled, he let me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before the trip, but there was little time to chat before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would be with us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim, and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group—not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was thrilled when I finally did it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in, reaching a comfortable speed, and stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, so did my speed and enjoyment of completing them. There seemed little need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come again next year.

Being a flight attendant isn't easy, but it's a rewarding job. Since I started, I've traveled all over, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and life is never dull, which is perfect for someone young like me. As a child, I went to a boarding school abroad, so I often flew alone. Feeling lonely, I would ask flight attendants if I could help serve meals, and some let me. This memory stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and find a new path. At the interview, there were many young people, and lots of them were accepted. They were often well-qualified, like me, and were changing careers. I prepared for the interview by talking about my strengths and past work experience, not just my love for travel, which everyone else would say. I got the job! I recommend this work to anyone because there are many benefits, but free flights aren't the main one. Airline staff work very hard, and there's a saying: "no-one's finished till everyone's finished." It's like a big family; even if we don't see each other often, we're still close. When I'm not working, I don't have to bring work home. If I do encounter difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won't see them again.

At the summer camp where I work, I love watching the children achieve things they never thought possible. Most of them already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is usually new for them. Some children feel very nervous at first, but with some encouragement, they all try it and eventually reach the top. This accomplishment makes them feel fantastic. 

At the start of the week, some children feel homesick. Surprisingly, it's not the youngest ones who miss home the most, but rather the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't allow them to use their mobile phones all the time. Initially, we tell them they can call home after lunch. If they ask again after dinner, we suggest it's too late and they should call the next day. Most children adjust within a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they thank us for the great time they've had.

It's not just the children who feel lonely; sometimes parents call frequently to check on their child, which isn't really necessary. Often, the child is busy playing games or doing activities, so we ask the parents to call back later. We also notice a certain type of child who arrives in expensive new clothes. These children often resist when we ask them to change into more suitable attire, but they soon understand why it's necessary.

"Rock the Planet" is a musical show where the actors also need to be excellent musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the 'Best Musical' award four times. However, using an all-British cast was challenging because the UK has stricter rules on how many shows young actors can perform each week compared to the USA. This meant they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have already won their first 'Best Musical' award. The London theatre is larger than the one in the USA, but it has been full every night, with audiences eager to hear the songs that became famous in America.

I spoke with Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, "It's amazing that I get paid to play, especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar." He explained how busy the young actors are, with regular school lessons at the theatre. "The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends," he said. His classmates came to see the show because the theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. "They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it's expensive for them," Jamie added.

When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found an extra one and invited me to join him and the other young actors. We played a song called "Days," which I didn't know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I was proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie's talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved the director wasn't there to hear my mistakes!

Although the young actors were already musicians, with some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together because they were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year and is definitely worth seeing.
